value.title: Dataflow Vs  Dataset   What are the Differences of these two Power BI Components
value.excerpt: I have presented about Power BI dataflow and datasets a lot, and always one of the questions I get is: What is the difference between dataflow and dataset. So I thought better to explain it in a post and help everyone in that understanding. In this video, you will learn what the differences between these

value.title: Get Data from Multiple Excel Files with Different Sheet Names into Power BI
value.excerpt: The ability to use Get Data from Folder in Power BI is a very useful option. However, if your sheet names are different in the list of Excel files, then you will face a problem. In this video, I’ll explain a method you can use that works regardless of the sheet names. Download the sample files from my
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/JZSdAvGAq_E" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Get the Day of the Week Name and Number in Power BI Using DAX
value.excerpt: If you don't have a date table with a column that represents the day of the week name (Saturday, Sunday, Monday etc) or number (from zero to six, or from one to seven), and you just have a date field, which you want to quickly get the day name of the week, here is a quick trick for you. Read my blog
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/hJJnyr1qxtk" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: One Dimension Filters Another Dimension in Power BI
value.excerpt: I often get this question after I explain about the star-schema. The question is that both my dimensions are filtering my fact table values, but how can I get one dimension filtering another dimension? for example, how can I get only the list of products that have been purchased by this customer? In
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/6Nu-1_a31iU" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Substring in DAX   How to get Part of String Field in Power BI Using DAX Expression
value.excerpt: Substring is one of the most common functions in many languages, However, there is no such function in DAX. There is a very simple way of doing it, which I am going to explain in this post. Substring means getting part of a string, for example from "Reza Rad", if I want to get the start starting from

value.title: Analyzing a slow report query in DAX Studio
value.excerpt: Investigate a slow query in a Power BI report using DAX Studio, looking at the query plan and the server timings. How to learn DAX: https://www.sqlbi.com/guides/dax/ DAX Studio: https://daxstudio.org/ Optimizing DAX Workshop: https://www.sqlbi.com/p/optimizing-dax-video-course/

value.title: Connecting Excel to Power BI Desktop using DAX Studio
value.excerpt: You can connect Excel to Power BI Desktop copying the connection string from Power BI Desktop. Useful to test your model for Excel consumption before publishing to Power BI service.

value.title: Counting working days in DAX
value.excerpt: This video describes a DAX technique to compute the number of working days between two dates. Article and download: https://sql.bi/80301

value.title: Introducing Performance Analyzer in Power BI Desktop
value.excerpt: Performance Analyzer is the first diagnostic tool to find the slower parts of a report. Find the slowest DAX query before starting a deeper investigation using DAX Studio. How to learn DAX: https://www.sqlbi.com/guides/dax/ DAX Studio: https://daxstudio.org/
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/1lfeW9283vA" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Mark as Date Table in Power BI
value.excerpt: Tabular models (including Power BI) require marking the Date table as a date table to get appropriate results with time intelligence calculations. This video explains why this setting is required. Article and download: https://sql.bi/670749

value.title: Using CONCATENATEX in DAX
value.excerpt: This video showcases the use of CONCATENATEX, a handy DAX function to return a list of values in a measure. Article and download: https://sql.bi/206871

value.title: Copy Measures Between 2 Power BI Files
value.excerpt: I first wrote this article back in Jan-2019 and have decided to come back and update it now.  With the recent enhanced External Tools Toolbar in Power BI Desktop, there has never been a better time to start to learn how to use these tools. Have you ever wondered if [...]Read More »

value.title: Track wild polar bears with AI
value.excerpt: Detect and track polar bears through photos using AI, then use Power BI to show where polar bears are being spotted.

images.title: Track wild polar bears with AI

value.title: Create and share your first Power BI report
value.excerpt: With Power BI you can create compelling visuals and reports. In this module you learn how to use Power BI Desktop to connect to data, build visuals, and create a report that you can share with others in your organization. Then you learn how to publish the report to the Power BI service, and let others see your insights and benefit from your work.

value.title: Set up continuous data export from Azure IoT Central to a Power BI app
value.excerpt: This module covers continuous data export from IoT Central. You use the scenario from the "Create your first Azure IoT Central app" Learn module, where you control a refrigerated truck. This module adds continuous data export to both Blob storage, and an Event Hub. Then, a Power BI app is built to read and display the telemetry data on a mobile phone.

images.title: Set up continuous data export from Azure IoT Central to a Power BI app

value.title: Identify anomalies by routing data via IoT Hub to a built-in ML model in Azure Stream Analytics
value.excerpt: Learn about Azure IoT Hub message routing, and Stream Analytics anomaly detection. Start by creating an app that simulates issues with conveyor belt vibration. Then, use the Azure portal to route all the data for archiving in blob storage. Finish by routing the vibration data to anomaly detection, using a built-in ML model.

images.title: Identify anomalies by routing data via IoT Hub to a built-in ML model in Azure Stream Analytics

value.title: Add calculated tables and columns to Power BI Desktop models
value.excerpt: By the end of this module, you'll be able to add calculated tables and calculated columns to your data model. You'll also be able to describe row context, which is used to evaluated calculated column formulas. Because it's possible to add columns to a table using Power Query, you'll also learn when it's best to create calculated columns instead of Power Query computed columns.

value.title: Use DAX iterator functions in Power BI Desktop models
value.excerpt: By the end of this module, you’ll learn what the family of iterator functions can do, and how to use them in your DAX calculations. Calculations will include custom summarizations, ranking, and concatenation.

value.title: Modify DAX filter context in Power BI Desktop models
value.excerpt: By the end of this module, you’ll be able to describe filter context, which is used to evaluated measure formulas. You’ll then learn why some calculations need to modify filter context, and that it can be achieved by using the CALCULATE function. You’ll learn how to configure the CALCULATE function with filters and filter modifiers.

value.title: Write DAX formulas for Power BI Desktop models
value.excerpt: In this module, you'll learn how to write DAX formulas to create calculated tables, calculated columns, and measures, which are different types of model calculations. Additionally, you'll learn how to write and format DAX formulas, which consist of expressions that use functions, operators, references to model objects, constants, and variables.
